content.text: Fill the cup to the marked level with water
Place the cup, containing the water, on the balance
Read and record its mass \(m\)
Leave the water in the cup for the next experiment
Calculate a value for the capacity \(V_{1}\), using your reading from **(a)(ii)** and the equation \(V_{1} = \frac{m}{\rho}\), where \(\rho = 1.00 \text{g} /\text{cm}^3\)
Method 1
In Method 1, the capacity \(V_{1}\) is determined from the mass of water in the cup
Carefully tip the water into the measuring cylinder
Read and record the volume \(V_{2}\) of the water in the measuring cylinder
Method 2
In Method 2, the capacity \(V_{2}\) is measured directly from the volume of water in the cup
Measure and record the diameter \(d_{1}\) of the top of the cup, as shown in Fig. 1.2
Measure and record the diameter \(d_{2}\) of the base of the cup
Measure and record the height \(h\) from the base to the marked level **MAX**
Calculate the average diameter \(D\) using your readings from **(c)(i)** and **(c)(ii)**, and
the equation \(D = \frac{(d_1 + d_2)}{2}\)
D =
Calculate an approximate value for the capacity \(V_{3}\), using your results from **(c)(iii)** and **(c)(iv)** and the equation \(V_{3} = \frac{\pi D^{2}h}{4}\)
Method 3
In Method 3, the capacity \(V_{3}\) is estimated using the average diameter of the cup considering the cup as an approximate cylinder
Fig. 1.2
State a possible practical source of inaccuracy in **Method 2** and a possible source of inaccuracy in **Method 3**
Method 2
Method 3
State an additional measurement which could be taken to give a more accurate result in **Method 1**
In this experiment, you will measure the capacity of a drinks cup by three methods capacity of a cup is the maximum volume of liquid that it will hold in normal use
You have been supplied with a cup on which the maximum level \(\mathbf{MAX}\) is marked both inside and out, as shown in Fig. 1.1. Do not fill the cup beyond this level
Pour approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker \(\mathbf{A}\)
Place the thermometer into the water. When the reading has stopped rising, measure the initial temperature of the hot water in the beaker and, at the same time, start the stopclock
Record this temperature at time \(t = 0\) s in the first row of Table 2.1
Measure, and record in the table, the temperature of the hot water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}\), \(60 \text{s}\), \(90 \text{s}\), \(120 \text{s}\), \(150 \text{s}\) and \(180 \text{s}\)
Remove the lid from beaker \(\mathbf{B}\) and pour approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Replace the lid
Repeat steps (a)(ii) and (a)(iii) for beaker \(\mathbf{B}\)
Complete the column headings and enter the values of \(t\) in the table
State from which beaker, if any, the rate of loss of thermal energy is the greater. Justify your answer by referring to your results
beaker
justification
State one condition that should be controlled to ensure that the comparison between beaker \(\mathbf{A}\) and beaker \(\mathbf{B}\) is a fair one
A student points out that the experiment does not test the effectiveness of insulation in reducing thermal energy loss
Suggest a change to this experiment which could be made so that the effect of insulation could be investigated. Explain why this change would help
suggestion
explanation
In this experiment, you will investigate methods of preventing loss of thermal energy

You are provided with two beakers labelled \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\). Beaker \(\mathbf{A}\) has a layer of insulation. Do not remove this insulation. Beaker \(\mathbf{B}\) has a lid but no insulation. You are also provided with a supply of hot water
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Connect the crocodile clip to the resistance wire at the position labelled A
Switch on
Read and record in Table 3.1, the potential difference \(V\) and the current \(I\). Switch off
Repeat step (a)(ii) with the crocodile clip at positions B, C, D, E and F
Plot a graph of \(V / V\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(I / \text{A}\) (\(x\)-axis)
Determine the gradient \(M\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
The gradient \(M\) is numerically equal to the resistance \(R\) of the power supply
Write down the resistance \(R\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
In this experiment, you will investigate the current and potential difference in an electric circuit
The circuit has been set up for you
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1
Draw a line about \(8\mathrm{cm}\) from the bottom of your ray-trace sheet. Label this line AB
Mark a point \(\mathbf{N}\), near the centre of \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Draw a normal to \(\mathbf{AB}\) at point \(\mathbf{N}\). Label the other end of this normal \(\mathbf{L}\)
Draw a line \(\mathbf{CD}\) passing through \(\mathbf{N}\) and at an angle \(\alpha\) to \(\mathbf{AB}\) where \(\alpha = 20^{\circ}\)
Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) some distance apart on line \(\mathbf{LN}\)
Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\)
Place the mirror on line \(\mathbf{CD}\) and view the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 4.1

Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) some distance apart so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\), and the pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), all appear exactly one behind the other. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\)
Remove the mirror and the pins
Repeat steps **(b)**, **(c)** and **(d)** for an angle \(\alpha = 30^{\circ}\), replacing pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) in their original positions in step **(c)**
Remove the mirror and the pins
Draw a line passing through the first \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) positions and reaching \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Repeat steps **(g)** and **(h)** for the second set of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) positions
(j) A student suggests that \(\theta\) should always be equal to \(2\alpha\)
State whether your experimental results support this idea. Justify your answer with reference to the results
statement
justification
Measure, and record in Table 4.1, the angle \(\theta\) between this line and the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\)
In this experiment, you will investigate the reflection of light by a plane mirror
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 4.1
ray-trace sheet
